awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled ultrasound for imaging and diagnosing musculoskeletal injuries
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to enable widespread adoption of ultrasound imaging for musculoskeletal (MSK) injuries. The ultrasound image analysis platform enabled by artificial intelligence (AI) developed during this SBIR may bring cost-effective diagnostic imaging to a broader patient population as the small form factor of the ultrasound instrument enables the technology to be used in a variety of settings, including doctors’ offices, physical therapy offices, and sports facilities. There are approximately 840,000 clinicians who see patients with MSK injuries. Each of these clinicians represents candidate customers for the platform, leading to a total addressable market in the U.S. of $1.7 billion.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to advance artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled ultrasound imaging technology. Sonography is the most operator-dependent medical imaging modality in use today, limiting the use of ultrasound imaging in musculoskeletal (MSK) evaluation. The proposed approach seeks to enable the wider adoption of ultrasound for diagnosing MSK injuries. This project involves the development of rigorous mathematical models to determine whether a frame sequence is properly aligned and determine if tendon tears in shoulder scans are diagnosable. A guidance system will be developed to aid in ultrasound probe placement so that consistent identification of tendon tear presence or absence is achieved. The proposed AI-enabled approach to ultrasound imaging and diagnostics may help practitioners position the ultrasound probe without the need to maintain precise angular positioning. Once at the correct starting position, the practitioner will move the probe in a pre-prescribed motion using a guidance system as needed for accurate and efficient image capture. The goal of the technology is to enable novice practitioners to capture relevant analyses to assist in providing a diagnosis and a treatment plan.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcome Report: Artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled ultrasound for imaging and diagnosing musculoskeletal injuries

Musculoskeletal injuries are the most common injuries in the world. Simultaneously, they are the most undiagnosed and under-treated. Most people don’t get diagnosed or receive proper treatment for their injuries. Left untreated, musculoskeletal injuries can fester over time and lead to irreversible problems and ballooning costs later in life. Current modalities for diagnosing musculoskeletal injuries consist of guesswork based on symptoms, expensive MRIs, or a wait and see approach. This is especially detrimental to underserved populations, who tend to have less free time and more limited funds than the average patient. Ultrasound has been widely proven to be an effective and inexpensive modality in diagnosing musculoskeletal injuries at the point of care. However, a steep learning curve has previously prevented its widespread use. We are building deep learning technology where any health practitioner, with very little experience, can leverage artificial intelligence to scan an ultrasound probe and obtain a reliable musculoskeletal diagnostic. To accomplish this, we set out to color code main anatomical structures as well as pathologies, and to build a guidance system to help acquire those images.

We found there wasn’t a significant amount of existing research in the field of Ultrasound AI. Much of the difficulty with ultrasound AI lies in the different body types as they interact with ultrasound probes at continually varying angles. Therefore, research and experimentation in best practices, design protocols, image segmentation, guidance, and pathology recognition required quite a bit of bandwidth. For example, traditional object detection modules failed terribly in this niche. We researched and built a number of AI modules using up/down sampling architectures to see how the theoretical results would apply to our real world application. We then optimized those models for best performance and indication. We were able to build a pathology prediction model for tendon tears in the shoulder that operated at 95% accuracy (image attached). In addition, we were able to build an image segmentation model for the bicep tendon (image attached). Experimentation and analysis revealed this project would require an extremely large amount of data to work across various body parts and broader populations. This is consistent with other research in the field. We also realized this data set would need to engender real world encounters by both novice and experienced practitioners across a wide variety of musculoskeletal body parts.

We created a vendor agnostic platform in which health practitioners (novice, intermediate, or expert) can submit ultrasound videos for diagnostic overview by certified musculoskeletal ultrasound experts. Ultrasound videos received are pipelined through an organized body part hierarchy for labeling and input into relevant AI modules. Novice practitioners can receive live side-by-side virtual walkthroughs with patients for musculoskeletal ultrasound exams, or can submit acceptable ultrasound videos independently to our vendor agnostic platform. This acts as a value added diagnostic service for practitioners, as well as a scalable data collection and labeling mechanism for maturation of AI modules across the musculoskeletal system. To help scale this service, we signed a partnership with a large ultrasound vendor, who fully integrated their mobile app with our platform.

We plan to grow our live side-by-side virtual walkthroughs and diagnostic services to help democratize ultrasound diagnostics for more and more novice practitioners. We plan to use the data from this endeavor to extend our AI modules for functionality across a broad and representative data set before applying for FDA clearance and commercialization. This will enable live color coding of base anatomical structures and pathologies for immediate and easy recognition by novice practitioners. Ultimately, this will provide an inexpensive and scalable solution for broad use of ultrasound for general musculoskeletal diagnosis. We believe this will provide earlier diagnosis to more people for less money, and subsequently increase the quality of care for patients, particularly those of underserved populations


Last Modified: 11/30/2023
Modified by: Rodrigo   Parra
